description: Borrowed from French fabrique, from Latin fabrica (“a workshop, art, trade, product of art, structure, fabric”), from faber (“artisan, workman”). Doublet of forge, borrowed from Old French.

entries.meaning: (archaic) The act of constructing, construction, fabrication.
examples: Tithe was received by the bishop  […]  for the fabric of the churches for the poor.

entries.meaning: (archaic) The structure of anything, the manner in which the parts of a thing are united; workmanship, texture, make.
A material made of fibers, a textile or cloth.
(petrology) The appearance of crystalline grains in a rock.
(computing) Interconnected nodes that look like a textile fabric when diagrammed.
examples: The Internet is a fabric of computers connected by routers.

verbs.description: fabric (third-person singular simple present fabrics, present participle fabricking, simple past and past participle fabricked)

examples: Fabricking and Carpeting a Room. If your ballroom's walls are in need of a paint job, or the space feels cavernous, or your tent is just looking too bare, you can have the ceiling and walls draped with fabric to create an intimate enclave.
